{{sexual orientation}} The hormonal theory of sexuality holds that, just as exposure to certain hormones plays a role in fetal [[sex differentiation]], such exposure also influences the [[sexual orientation]] that emerges later in the adult. '''Prenatal hormones''' may be seen as the primary determinant of adult sexual orientation, or a co-factor with genes, [[Biology and sexual orientation|biological factors]] and/or environmental and social conditions.
==Sex-typed behavior==
The hormonal theory of sexuality and gender identity holds that, just as exposure to certain [[hormones]] plays a role in fetal sex differentiation, such exposure also influences the sexual orientation and or gender identity that emerges later in the adult. Differences in brain structure that come about from chemical messengers and genes interacting on developing brain cells are believed to be the basis of sex differences in countless behaviors, including sexual orientation.<ref name=Garcia>Garcia-Falgueras A, Swaab DF. Sexual hormones and the brain: an essential alliance for sexual identity and sexual orientation. Endocr Dev. 2010;17:22-35. {{DOI|10.1159/000262525}} {{PMID|19955753}}</ref>{{rp|25}} Prenatal factors that affect or interfere with the interaction of these hormones on the developing brain can influence later [[Childhood gender nonconformity|sex-typed behavior]] in children.<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}} This hypothesis is originated from countless experimental studies in non-human mammals, yet the argument that similar effects can be seen in human neurobehavioral development is a much debated topic among scholars.<ref name="Hines Review" /> Recent studies, however, have provided evidence in support of prenatal androgen exposure influencing childhood sex-typed behavior.<ref name="Hines Review">{{cite journal|last=Hines|first=Melissa|title=Sex-related variation in human behavior and the brain.|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|date=October 2010|volume=14|issue=10|pages=448–456|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2010.07.005|pmid=20724210|pmc=2951011}}</ref>
Fetal hormones may be seen as either the primary influence upon adult sexual orientation or as a co-factor interacting with genes and/or environmental and social conditions.<ref name=BornGay>Wilson, G., & Q. Rahman, ''Born Gay: The Psychobiology of Human Sex Orientation'', Peter Owen Publishers; 2nd edition (May 1, 2008) {{ISBN|9780720613094}}</ref>{{page needed|date=January 2015}} However, Garcia-Falgueras and [[Dick Swaab]] disagree that social conditions influence sexual orientation to a large degree. As seen in young children as well as in vervet and rhesus monkeys, sexually differentiated behavior in toy preference is differing in males versus females, where females prefer dolls and males prefer toy balls and cars; these preferences can be seen as early as 3–8 months in humans.<ref name="Hines Review" /> It is impossible to completely rule out the social environment or the child's cognitive understanding of gender when discussing sex typed play in androgen-exposed girls.<ref name="Hines Review" /> Conversely, children tend towards objects which have been labelled for their own sex, or toys that they have seen members of their sex playing with previously.<ref name="Hines Review" />
An endocrinology study by Garcia-Falgueras and Swaab postulated that "In humans, the main mechanism responsible of {{sic}} sexual identity and orientation involves a direct effect of testosterone on the developing brain."<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|25}} Further, their study puts forward that intrauterine exposure to hormones is largely determinative. Sketching the argument briefly here, the authors say that sexual organs are differentiated first, and then the brain is sexually differentiated "under the influence, mainly, of sex hormones such as testosterone, estrogen and progesterone on the developing brain cells and under the presence of different genes as well ... . The changes brought about in this stage are permanent. ... [S]exual differentiation of the brain is not caused by hormones alone, even though they are very important for gender identity and sexual orientation."<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}}
===Organizational aspects===
Fetal gonads develop primarily based on the presence or absence of [[androgen]] hormones, mainly [[testosterone]], [[dihydrotestosterone]] (DHT) and [[androstenedione]]; production of testosterone and conversion into dihydrotestosterone during weeks 6 to 12 of pregnancy are key factors in the production of a male fetus's penis, scrotum and prostate.<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain" /> In a female, on the other hand, absence of these levels of androgens results in development of typically female genitals.<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain" /> Following this, sexual differentiation of the brain occurs; sex hormones exert organizational effects on the brain that will be activated in puberty.<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain">{{cite journal|last=Bao|first=Ai-Min|author2=Dick F. Swaab|title=Sexual differentiation of the human brain: Relation to gender identity, sexual orientation and neuropsychiatric disorders|journal=Frontiers in Neuroendocrinology|date=18 February 2011|volume=32|issue=2|pages=214–226|doi=10.1016/j.yfrne.2011.02.007|pmid=21334362}}</ref> As a result of these two processes occurring separately, the degree of genital masculinization does not necessarily relate to the masculinization of the brain.<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}}<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain" /> Sex differences in the brain have been found in many structures, most notably the [[hypothalamus]] and the [[amygdala]].<ref name="Hines Review" /> However, few of these have been related to behavioral sex differences, and scientists are still working to establish firm links between early hormones, brain development and behavior.<ref name="Hines Review" /> The study of the organizational theory of prenatal hormones can be difficult, as ethically researchers cannot alter hormones in a developing fetus; instead, scholars must rely on naturally occurring abnormalities of development to provide answers.<ref name=Berenbaum>{{cite journal|last=Berenbaum|first=Sheri A.|author2=Adriene M. Beltz|title=Sexual differentiation of human behavior: Effects of prenatal and pubertal organizational hormones|journal=Frontiers in Endocrinology|date=April 2011|volume=32|issue=2|pages=183–200|doi=10.1016/j.yfrne.2011.03.001|pmid=21397624}}</ref>
Most extensively studied in organizational effects of hormones is [[congenital adrenal hyperplasia]] (CAH).<ref name=hinesrev2011>{{cite journal |last=Hines |first=Melissa |year=2011 |title=Prenatal endocrine influences on sexual orientation and on sexually differentiated childhood behavior |journal=Frontiers in Neuroendocrinology |volume=32 |issue=2 |pages=170–182 |doi=10.1016/j.yfrne.2011.02.006 |pmid=21333673|pmc=3296090}}</ref> CAH is a genetic disease that results in exposure to high levels of [[androgens]] beginning early in gestation. Girls with CAH are born with masculinized genitalia, which is corrected surgically as soon as possible.<ref name=Berenbaum/><ref name=hinesrev2011/> CAH provides the opportunity for [[natural experiments]], as people with CAH can be compared to people without it. However, "CAH is not a perfect experiment", since, "social responses to masculinized genitalia or factors related to the disease itself" can [[confound]] results.<ref name=Berenbaum/> Nonetheless several studies have shown that CAH has a clear but not determining influence on sexual orientation; women with CAH are less likely to be exclusively heterosexual than are other women.<ref name=hinesrev2011/>
Since hormones alone do not determine sexual orientation and differentiation of the brain, the search for other factors that act upon sexual orientation have led genes such as the [[SRY]] and ZFY to be implicated.<ref name="Ngun et al">{{cite journal|last=Ngun|first=Tuck C. |author2=Negar Ghahramani |author3=Francisco J. Sanchez |author4=Sven Bocklandt |author5=Eric Vilain|title=The genetics of sex differences in brain and behavior|journal=Frontiers in Neuroendocrinology|date=October 2010|volume=32|issue=2|pages=227–246|doi=10.1016/j.yfrne.2010.10.001|pmid=20951723|pmc=3030621 }}</ref>
===Prenatal maternal stress===
As of 2006 results from studies in humans had found conflicting evidence regarding the effect of prenatal exposure to hormones and psychosexual outcomes; Gooren noted in 2006 that studies in subprimate mammals are invalid measures of human sexual differentiation, as sex hormones follow a more "on-off" role in sex-typed behavior than is found in primates.<ref name=Gooren>{{cite journal|last=Gooren|first=Louis|title=The biology of human psychosexual differentiation|journal=Hormones and Behavior|date=November 2006|volume=50|issue=4|pages=589–601|doi=10.1016/j.yhbeh.2006.06.011|pmid=16870186}}</ref>
Some studies do suggest that prenatal stress significantly increases the likelihood of [[homosexuality]] or [[bisexuality]], although varying evidence exists for which trimester is most important.<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}} Studies of endocrinology have found implications for amphetamines and thyroid-gland hormones to increase homosexuality in female offspring as well, although it has not been examined in conjunction with prenatal stress levels.<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}}
Some have postulated that postnatal (e.g., social and environmental factors) development can play a role in the sexual orientation of an individual, yet solid evidence of this has yet to be discovered. Children born through artificial insemination with donor sperm and consequently raised by lesbian couples have typically been heterosexually oriented.<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}}<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain" /> Summed up by Bao and Swaab, "The apparent impossibility of getting someone to change their sexual orientation ... is a major argument against the importance of the social environment in the emergence of homosexuality, as well as against the idea that homosexuality is a lifestyle choice."<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain" />
===Male homosexuality as hypermasculine=== {{main|Hypermasculinity}}
There is evidence of a correlation between sexual orientation and traits that are determined [[in utero]].<ref name=BornGay/>{{page needed|date=November 2017}} A study by McFadden in 1998 found that auditory systems in the [[brain]], another physical trait influenced by prenatal hormones is different in those of differing orientations; likewise the [[suprachiasmatic nucleus]] was found by Swaab and Hofman to be larger in homosexual men than in heterosexual men.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Panzica|first1=GC|last2=Aste|first2=N|last3=Viglietti-Panzica|first3=C|last4=Ottinger|first4=MA|title=Structural sex differences in the brain: influence of gonadal steroids and behavioral correlates.|journal=[[Journal of Endocrinological Investigation]]|date=March 1995|volume=18|issue=3|pages=232–52|doi=10.1007/BF03347808|pmid=7615911}}</ref> The suprachiasmatic nucleus is also known to be larger in men than in women.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0165-3806(94)90129-5 |vauthors=Swaab DF, Zhou JN, Ehlhart T, Hofman MA |title=Development of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide neurons in the human suprachiasmatic nucleus in relation to birth and sex |journal=Brain Res. Dev. Brain Res. |volume=79 |issue=2 |pages=249–59 |date=June 1994 |pmid=7955323 }}</ref> An analysis of the hypothalamus by Swaab and Hofmann (1990;2007) found that the volume of the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) in homosexual men was 1.7 times larger than a reference group of male subjects, and contained 2.1 times as many cells.<ref name=Gooren /><ref name="Swaab and Hogman 1990;2007">{{cite journal|last=Swaab|first=Dick|author2=M.A. Hofman|title=An enlarged suprachiasmatic nucleus in homosexual men.|journal=Brain Research|date=December 1990|volume=537|issue=1–2|pages=141–148|doi=10.1016/0006-8993(90)90350-K|pmid=2085769}}</ref> During development, the volume of the SCN and the cell counts reach peak value at approximately 13 to 16 months after birth; at this age, the SCN contains the same number of cells as was found in adult male homosexuals, yet in a reference group of heterosexual males the cell numbers begin to decline to the adult value of 35% of the peak value.<ref name=Gooren /> These results have yet to be replicated, however; there also has yet to be a meaningful interpretation of these results provided in the context of human sexual orientation.<ref name=Gooren /> Some studies suggest gay men have also been shown to have higher levels of circulating androgens<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Brodie HK, Gartrell N, Doering C, Rhue T |title=Plasma testosterone levels in heterosexual and homosexual men |journal=Am J Psychiatry |volume=131 |issue=1 |pages=82–3 |date=January 1974 |pmid=4808435 |url=http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=4808435 |doi=10.1176/ajp.131.1.82}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Further Studies on Sex Hormones in Male Homosexuals|year=1976|author=Peter Doerr|displayauthors=etal|journal=Arch Gen Psychiatry|volume=33|issue=5|pages=611–614|doi=10.1001/archpsyc.1976.01770050063010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Sex Differences in Cognition: The Role of Testosterone and Sexual Orientation|author1=Nick Neave|author2=Meyrav Menaged|author3=David R. Weightman|volume=41|pages=245–262|journal=Brain and Cognition|doi=10.1006/brcg.1999.1125|pmid=10585237|date=December 1999}}</ref> and larger penises,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1023/A:1018780108597 |vauthors=Bogaert AF, Hershberger S |title=The relation between sexual orientation and penile size |journal=Arch Sex Behav |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=213–21 |date=June 1999 |pmid=10410197 |url=http://www.kluweronline.com/art.pdf?issn=0004-0002&volume=28&page=213}}</ref> on average, than heterosexual men.
====Fraternal birth order==== According to some studies, gay men have more older [[brother]]s on average, a phenomenon known as the [[Fraternal birth order and sexual orientation|fraternal birth order effect]]. It has been suggested that the greater the number of older male siblings the higher the level of [[androgen]] fetuses are exposed to<!--I think this is a reference to Williams et al. Nature paper, but I don't think it says quite says what this last sentence says-->. No evidence of birth order effects have been observed in women. The theory holds that the fraternal birth order effect is a result of a maternal immune response that is produced towards a factor of male development over several male pregnancies.<ref name="Kinsey data" /> Bogaert's hypothesis argues that "the target of the immune response may be malespecific molecules on the surface of male fetal brain cells (e.g., including those in the anterior hypothalamus). Antimale antibodies might bind to these molecules and thus interfere with their role in normal sexual differentiation, leading some later born males to being attracted to men as opposed to women."<ref name="Kinsey data" /> Garcia-Falgueras and Swaab state that "The ... fraternal birth order effect ... is putatively explained by an immunological response by the mother to a product of the Y chromosome of her sons. The chance of such an immune response to male factors would increase with every pregnancy resulting in the birth of a son."<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}}
While direct support has not been found for these hypotheses, evidence that favours this theory exists.<ref name="Blanchard/Lippa cite">{{cite journal|last=Blanchard|first=Ray|author2=Richard Lippa|title=Birth Order, Sibling Sex Ratio, Handedness, and Sexual Orientation of Male and Female Participants in a BBC Internet Research Project|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|date=April 2007|volume=36|issue=2|pages=163–176|doi=10.1007/s10508-006-9159-7|pmid=17345165}}</ref> Further, while percentages of the likelihood of homosexuality have been estimated to be increased by 15<ref>{{cite journal|title=Birth Order, Sibling Sex Ratio, Handedness, and Sexual Orientation of Male and Female Participants in a BBC Internet Research Project|author1=Ray Blanchard|author2=Richard Lippa|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|year=2007|volume=36|issue=2|pages=163–76|doi=10.1007/s10508-006-9159-7|pmid=17345165}}</ref>–48% per older brother, these odds really account for only a few percent of the population; thus, this hypothesis cannot be universally applied to the majority of homosexual men.<ref name=Gooren /> Not all studies have been able to reproduce the fraternal birth order effect. Some did not find any statistically significant difference in either the sibling composition or rate of older brothers of gay and straight men,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Do shared etiological factors contribute to the relationship between sexual orientation and depression?|year=2012|journal=Psychological Medicine|volume=42|pages=521–532|author1=B. P. Zietsch|doi=10.1017/S0033291711001577|display-authors=etal|pmid=21867592|pmc=3594769}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10508-014-0474-0|title=Fraternal Birth Order and Extreme Right-Handedness as Predictors of Sexual Orientation and Gender Nonconformity in Men|author1=Mariana Kishida|author2=Qazi Rahman|year=2015|journal=[[Archives of Sexual Behavior]]|doi=10.1007/s10508-014-0474-0|volume=44|pages=1493–1501}}</ref> including large, nationally representative studies in the US and Denmark.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1080/00224490802398357|journal=J. Sex Res.|year=2008|author1=Francis AM|title=Family and sexual orientation: the family-demographic correlates of homosexuality in men and women|volume=45|issue=4|pages=371–7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Childhood family correlates of heterosexual and homosexual marriages: a national cohort study of two million Danes|year=2006|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|volume=35|issue=5|pages=533–47|author1=Frisch M|author2=Hviid A|doi=10.1007/s10508-006-9062-2|pmid=17039403}}</ref>
In conjunction with fraternal birth order, [[Handedness and sexual orientation|handedness]] provides further evidence of prenatal effects on sexual orientation, because handedness is regarded by many as a marker of early neurodevelopment. Other correlates to handedness (e.g., cerebral laterality, prenatal hormonal profiles, spatial ability) have been linked to sexual orientation, either empirically and/or theoretically.<ref name="Kinsey data" /> In right-handed individuals, the number of older brothers increased the odds of homosexual orientation, but this effect was not seen in left-handed individuals.<ref name="Kinsey data" /> As with other purported marks indicating higher incidence of homosexuality, however, the link with handedness remains ambiguous and several studies have been unable to replicate it.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1023/A:1014039403752 | pmid = 11910784 | year = 2002 | last1 = Mustanski | first1 = B. S. | last2 = Bailey | first2 = J. M. | last3 = Kaspar | first3 = S. | title = Dermatoglyphics, handedness, sex, and sexual orientation | volume = 31 | issue = 1 | pages = 113–122 | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Finger-length ratios and sexual orientation|url=https://www.msu.edu/~breedsm/pdf/breedlove2000.pdf|year=2000|author1=Terrance J. Williams|journal=Nature|issue=6777|doi=10.1038/35006555|pages=455–456|author2=Michelle E. Pepitone|author3=Scott E. Christensen|author4=Bradley M. Cooke|author5=Andrew D. Huberman|author6=Nicholas J. Breedlove|author7=Tessa J. Breedlove|author8=Cynthia L. Jordan|author9=S. Marc Breedlove|pmid=10761903|volume=404}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1037/a0014816 | title = Hair Whorl Direction and Sexual Orientation in Human Males | year = 2009 | author1 = Qazi Rahman | author2 = Kenneth Clarke | author3 = Tirma Morera | journal = Behavioral Neuroscience | volume = 123 | issue = 2 | pages = 252–256 | pmid=19331448 }}</ref>
=====Implicated genes in fraternal birth order=====
A gene of the ''Rh'' system has been discussed as a possible candidate for affecting fraternal birth order, as it has been linked to both handedness and immune system functioning.<ref name="Kinsey data">{{cite journal|last=Bogaert|first=Anthony|author2=Ray Blanchard |author3=Lesley Crothswait |title=Interaction of Birth Order, Handedness, and Sexual Orientation in the Kinsey Interview Data|journal=Behavioral Neuroscience|date=October 2007|volume=121|issue=5|pages=845–853|doi=10.1037/0735-7044.121.5.845|pmid=17907817}}</ref> Gene variants in the ''Rh'' system are implicated in a maternal response to what is known as [[hemolytic disease of the newborn]]. ''Rh'' is a factor in blood, and in cases where the mother is absent of this (''Rh-'') while carrying an ''Rh+'' fetus, an immune response may develop with deleterious effects. The ''Rh'' gene hypothesis is a strong candidate because not only does it involve the maternal immune response, but it has been implicated in handedness as well.<ref name="Kinsey data" />
Variants of the androgen receptor (''AR'') gene have also been discussed, in that non-right-handedness in men has been linked with greater CAG repeats in the ''AR'' gene, which in turn is associated with lower testosterone. A theory that high prenatal testosterone leads to neuronal and axonal loss in the corpus callosum is supported by this hypothesis.<ref name=Witelson>{{cite journal|last=Witelson|first=Sandra|author2=R. S. Nowakowski|title=Left out axons make men right: A hypothesis for the origin of handedness and functional asymmetry|journal=Neuropsychologia|year=1991|volume=29|issue=4|pages=327–333|doi=10.1016/0028-3932(91)90046-B}}</ref>
===Male homosexuality as hypomasculine=== {{main|Hypomasculinity}}
In a 1991 study, [[Simon LeVay]] demonstrated that a tiny clump <!--name that 'clump' (& call it a nucleus) --> of neurons of the anterior [[hypothalamus]]—which is believed to control sexual behavior and linked to prenatal hormones—known as the interstitial nuclei of the anterior was, on average, more than twice the size in heterosexual men when contrasted to homosexual men. Due to this area also being nearly twice the size in heterosexual men than in heterosexual women, the implication is that the sexual differentiation of the hypothalamus in homosexuals is in a female direction.<ref name=Gooren /> In 2003 scientists at [[Oregon State University]] announced that they had replicated his findings in sheep. Later studies in humans, however, have yet to confirm this finding.<ref name=Gooren /> <!-- I believe this has also been replicated in human subjects: Byne, W., S. Tobet, ''et al.'' (2001). "The interstitial nuclei of the human anterior hypothalamus: an investigation of variation with sex, sexual orientation, and hiv status." Horm Behav 40(2): 86–92. Dr. Simon LeVay, in his study of the hypothalamic differences between the brains of homosexual and heterosexual men, offered the following criticisms of his own research, "It's important to stress what I didn't find. I did not prove that homosexuality is genetic, or find a genetic cause for being gay. I didn't show that gay men are born that way, the most common mistake people make in interpreting my work. Nor did I locate a gay center in the brain."-->
===Female homosexuality===
Most empirical or theoretical research into women's sexual orientation has, historically, been guided by the idea of lesbians as essentially masculine and heterosexual women as essentially feminine.<ref name=Peplau>{{cite journal|last=Peplau|first=Letitia|author2=Mark Huppin|title=Masculinity, Femininity and the Development of Sexual Orientation in Women|journal=Journal of Gay & Lesbian Mental Health|date=October 2008|volume=12|issue=1–2|pages=145–165|doi=10.1300/J529v12n01_09}}</ref> Typically, this belief is traced to the early "inversion theory" of sex researchers who state that homosexuality is a result of biological abnormalities that "invert" sexual attraction and personality.<ref name="Peplau" /> Handedness research has provided implications; because more men than women present a preference for their left hand, the higher proportion of non-right handedness that has been discovered among lesbians when compared to heterosexual women demonstrates a possible link of prenatal masculinization and sexual orientation.<ref name="Peplau" /> Backing this up are reports that lesbians display more masculinized 2D;4D digit ratios than heterosexual women, based on data gathered from at least six different laboratories.<ref name="2d4d twins" /> This effect has not yet been observed between homosexual and heterosexual males.<ref name="2d4d twins">{{cite journal|last=Gobrogge|first=Kyle L|author2=S. Marc Breedlove |author3=Kelly L. Klump |title=Genetic and Environmental Influences on 2D;4D Finger Length Ratios: A Study of Monozygotic and Dizygotic Male and Female Twins|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|date=February 2008|volume=37|issue=1|pages=112–118|doi=10.1007/s10508-007-9272-2|pmid=18074216}}</ref> However, the validity of this measure of digit ratios remains controversial as a predictor of prenatal androgen, as many other prenatal factors may play roles in bone growth in prenatal stages of development.<ref name=Gooren /> While many studies have found results confirming this hypothesis, others have failed to replicate these findings,<ref name=Gooren /> leaving the validity of this measure unconfirmed.
[[Diethylstilbestrol]] (DES), a drug that has been in the past prescribed to prevent miscarriages, has also been studied in relation to women's sexual orientation. It has been observed to exert a masculinizing/defeminizing effect on the developing brain of the fetus.<ref name=Peplau /> When compared to controls, higher percentages of DES-exposed women (17% vs 0%) reported that they had engaged in same-sex relations; however, the great majority of DES women stated an exclusively heterosexual orientation.<ref name="Peplau" />
Girls with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (an autosomal recessive condition which results in high androgen levels during fetal development) have more masculinized sex role identities and are more likely to have a homosexual sexual orientation as adults than controls.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dittmann|first=V|author2=Dilling H. |date=June 1990|title=Chapter V (F) of ICD-10: mental, behavioural and developmental disorders—introduction and overview.|journal=Pharmacopsychiatry|volume=23|issue=suppl 4|pages=137–41|pmid=2197637|doi=10.1055/s-2007-1014552}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dittmann V, von Cranach M, Eckermann G |title=Abnormalities of adult personality and behaviour (section F 6)--results of the ICD-10 field trial |journal=Pharmacopsychiatry |volume=23 Suppl 4 |issue= |pages=170–2 |year=1990 |pmid=2197643 |doi=10.1055/s-2007-1014559 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Dittmann|first=V|date=1992-08-01|title=[ICD-10 in psychiatric diagnosis. The concept and initial practical experiences]|journal= Versicherungsmedizin|volume=44|issue=4|pages=114–9|pmid=1509643|language=German}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Zucker|first=KJ|author2=Bradley SJ |author3=Oliver G |author4=Blake J |author5=Fleming S |author6=Hood J. |date=December 1996|title=Psychosexual development of women with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. |journal=Horm Behav|volume=30|issue=4|pages=300–18|pmid=9047259|doi=10.1006/hbeh.1996.0038}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/00224490409552215 |vauthors=Hines M, Brook C, Conway GS |title=Androgen and psychosexual development: core gender identity, sexual orientation and recalled childhood gender role behavior in women and men with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) |journal=J Sex Res |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=75–81 |date=February 2004 |pmid=15216426 }}</ref> An alternative explanation for this effect is the fact that girls with this condition are born with masculinized external genitalia, which leads their parents to raise them in a more masculine manner, thus influencing their sexual orientation as adults. However, the degree to which the girls' genitals are masculinized does not correlate with their sexual orientation, suggesting that prenatal hormones are a stronger causal factor, not parental influence.
Together with congenital adrenal hyperplasia, DES studies have provided little support of the prenatal hormone theory of sexual orientation; they do, however, provide the framework for possible pathways to a homosexual orientation for a small number of women.<ref name="Peplau" />
===Gender dysphoria=== {{main|Gender dysphoria}}
In individuals with [[gender dysphoria]], previously known as gender identity disorder (GID), prenatal exposure to testosterone has been hypothesized to have an effect on gender identity differentiation. The 2D;4D finger ratio, or relative lengths of the 2nd "index" and 4th "ring" fingers, has become a popular measure of prenatal androgen because of accumulated evidence suggesting the 2D;4D ratios are related to prenatal exposure to testosterone.<ref name="2d4d wallien">{{cite journal|last=Wallien|first=Madeleine|author2=Kenneth J. Zucker |author3=Thomas D. Steensma |author4=Peggy T. Cohen-Kettenis |title=2D:4D finger-length ratios in children and adults with gender identity disorder|journal=Hormones and Behavior|date=August 2008|volume=54|issue=3|pages=450–454|doi=10.1016/j.yhbeh.2008.05.002|pmid=18585715}}</ref> Many children with GID differentiate a homosexual orientation during adolescence, but not all of them; adults with "early onset", or a childhood history of cross-gender behavior, often have a homosexual orientation. Adults with "late onset", or those without a childhood history of said behavior, are more likely to have a non-homosexual orientation.<ref name="2d4d wallien"/>
Prenatal androgen exposure has been associated with an increased chance of patient-initiated [[Sex reassignment surgery|gender reassignment]] to male after being initially raised as female in early childhood or infancy.<ref name=Gooren /><ref name="Meyer-Bahlburg 2005">{{cite journal|last=Meyer-Bahlburg|first=Heino|title=gender identity outcome in female-raised 46,XY persons with penile agenesis, cloacal exstrophy of the bladder, or penile albation|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|date=28 August 2005|volume=34|issue=4|pages=423–438|doi=10.1007/s10508-005-4342-9}}</ref> Gooren found that organizational effects of prenatal androgens are more prevalent in gender role behavior than in gender identity, and that there are preliminary findings that suggest evidence of a male gender identity being more frequent in patients with fully male-typical prenatal androgenization.<ref name=Gooren />
Individuals with complete [[androgen insensitivity syndrome]] are almost always brought up as females, and the differentiation of gender identity/role is feminine.<ref name=Gooren /> This example is important in demonstrating that chromosomes and gonads alone do not dictate gender identity and role.<ref name=Gooren />
====Transsexualism==== {{main|Transsexualism}}
Because organ differentiation and brain differentiation occur at different times, in rare cases transsexualism can result.<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|24}} Only 23% of childhood gender problems will result in transsexuality in adulthood.<ref name="Sexual Differentiation of the Brain" />
Drawing on some transsexualism cases, Garcia-Falgueras and Swaab state that "[f]rom these examples it appears that the direct action of testosterone on the developing brain in boys and the lack of such action on the developing brain in girls are crucial factors in the development of male and female gender identity and sexual orientation ... ."<ref name=Garcia/>{{rp|26}} Countless studies have been run on peripheral levels of sex steroids in male and female homosexuals, a considerable number of which claimed to find "less 'male hormone' and/or more 'female hormone' in male homosexuals and vice versa in female homosexuals".<ref name=Gooren /> However, these findings have been reviewed and have subsequently been dismissed by scholars as suffering from faulty design and interpretation.<ref name=Gooren />
Factors implicated in the development of transsexuality include chromosomal abnormalities, polymorphisms of certain genes, and variations in [[aromatase]] (cytochrome P450 CYP19) and [[CYP17]].<ref name=Gooren /> Girls with congenital adrenal hyperplasia show an increase in probability of transsexuality later in life; however, this risk is still only 1–3% in CAH.<ref name=Gooren /> Although historically abnormal sexual differentiation has pointed to androgens as a causal factor, there are codeterminants of gender identity and sexual orientation with overriding effects of androgens on the brain, in male transsexuals or homosexuals, or making androgen effects on the brain redundant, as in female transsexuals or homosexuals.<ref name=Gooren /> These factors are currently unknown, and thus no clear cut answer for the cause of transsexualism and homosexuality exists.<ref name=Gooren />
Due to relatively small population sizes, generalizability of studies on transsexuality cannot be assumed.
==Endocrine disruptors== [[Endocrine disruptors|Endocrine disrupting chemicals]] (EDCs) are chemicals that, at certain doses, can interfere with the endocrine system in mammals.<ref>Staff, NIEHS. Last Reviewed, June 05, 2013. [http://www.niehs.nih.gov/health/topics/agents/endocrine/ Endocrine Disruptors]</ref> Work on possible [[Neurotoxin|neurotoxic]] effects of endocrine disruptors, and their possible effects on sexual orientation when a fetus is exposed to them, is in its infancy: "we mostly know about the relationship between EDC exposure and neurobehavioral function through an examination of outcomes within a limited sphere of questions."<ref name=intersect>{{cite journal |last=Weiss |first=Bernard |date=2013-12-01 |title=The Intersection of Neurotoxicology and Endocrine Disruption |journal=Neurotoxicology |volume=33 |issue=6 |pages=1410–1419 |doi=10.1016/j.neuro.2012.05.014 |pmid=22659293|pmc=3458140}}</ref> While studies have found that [[xenoestrogens]] and [[xenoandrogens]] can alter the brain's sexual differentiation in a number of species used as [[animal models]],<ref>{{cite journal |last=Roselli |first=C.E. |last2=Stormshak |first2=F. |date=2009 |title=Prenatal Programming of Sexual Partner Preference |journal=J. Neuroendocrinol |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=359–364 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2826.2009.01828.x |pmid=19207819|pmc=2668810}}</ref> from the data in hand to date, it is "misleading ...to expect EDCs to produce profiles of effects, such as sexually dimorphic behaviors, as literal copies of those produced by native hormones. Such agents are not hormones. They should not be expected to act precisely as hormones."<ref name=intersect/>
==See also== * [[Biology and sexual orientation]] * [[Environment and sexual orientation]] * [[Handedness and sexual orientation]] * [[Genetics of gender]] * [[David Reimer]] * [[Epigenetic theories of homosexuality]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Green, R. (1987). ''The "sissy boy syndrome" and the development of homosexuality.'' New Haven, CT: Yale University Press. *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0306-4530(90)90065-H |vauthors=Dittmann RW, Kappes MH, Kappes ME, etal |title=Congenital adrenal hyperplasia. I: Gender-related behavior and attitudes in female patients and sisters |journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology |volume=15 |issue=5–6 |pages=401–20 |year=1990 |pmid=2101963 }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0306-4530(90)90066-I |vauthors=Dittmann RW, Kappes MH, Kappes ME, etal |title=Congenital adrenal hyperplasia. II: Gender-related behavior and attitudes in female salt-wasting and simple-virilizing patients |journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology |volume=15 |issue=5–6 |pages=421–34 |year=1990 |pmid=2101964 }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0306-4530(92)90054-B |vauthors=Dittmann RW, Kappes ME, Kappes MH |title=Sexual behavior in adolescent and adult females with congenital adrenal hyperplasia |journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology |volume=17 |issue=2–3 |pages=153–70 |year=1992 |pmid=1438641 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0306-4530(92)90054-B}} *{{cite journal |author=Rahman Q |title=The neurodevelopment of human sexual orientation |journal=Neurosci Biobehav Rev |volume=29 |issue=7 |pages=1057–66 |year=2005 |pmid=16143171 |doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2005.03.002 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0149-7634(05)00032-1}} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Williams TJ, Pepitone ME, Christensen SE, etal |title=Finger-length ratios and sexual orientation |journal=Nature |volume=404 |issue=6777 |pages=455–6 |date=March 2000 |pmid=10761903 |doi=10.1038/35006555 |url=http://msu.edu/~breedsm/pdf/breedlove2000.pdf}} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Zucker KJ, Bradley SJ, Oliver G, Blake J, Fleming S, Hood J |title=Psychosexual development of women with congenital adrenal hyperplasia |journal=Horm Behav |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=300–18 |date=December 1996 |pmid=9047259 |doi=10.1006/hbeh.1996.0038 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0018-506X(96)90038-0}}

{{multiple issues| {{Advert|date=July 2011}} {{Notability|date=July 2011}} }} [[File:ROV and logo sm.jpg|frame|right|100 px|RPMNF's ROV recording the 4th-century CE Joni wreck site in Albania. Photo H. Phoenix, RPMNF.]] '''RPM Nautical Foundation''' is a non-profit [[archaeological]] research and educational organization dedicated to the advancement of [[maritime archaeology]] that includes littoral surveys and excavation of individual [[shipwreck]] and [[harbor]] sites. RPM Nautical Foundation (RPMNF) is organized to operate exclusively for charitable, scientific, literary and educational purposes, all within the meaning of sections [[Charitable contribution deductions in the United States|170(c)(2) and 501(c)(3)]] of the [[United States Internal Revenue Code]]. The operating purpose of the company is to engage in the detection, identification, study and preservation of nautical archaeological and [[historic site]]s for scientific research, public education, the advancement of technology. The organization also provides fieldwork and training experience in the field to students as well as the personnel and staff of various government, cultural and educational institutions. Among the goals for RPMNF is the effort to assist [[Mediterranean countries]] with the location, identification, assessment, and research of their submerged cultural material so that these important cultural resources can be protected for future generations. Accordingly, RPMNF projects are carried out in conjunction with host governments in the Mediterranean and serve as a crucial component in the effort to protect submerged archaeological sites and maritime heritage in association with UNESCO’s efforts to preserve world heritage sites. RPMNF policy stipulates that all artifacts are under the jurisdiction of the host government at all times. The location and assessment of [[Shipwreck|wreck sites]], as well as site and artifact analysis is beneficial to the many governments that RPMNF works with, as it provides cultural authorities pertinent information for protecting archaeological resources. Over the past decade RPMNF has made advances in maritime archaeology of the littoral region of the Mediterranean through intensive and systematic use of technology. RPMNF’s research vessel, the R/V Hercules, is a purpose-built maritime archaeological platform that has seafloor mapping and three-dimensional modeling capabilities for identification of submerged cultural material sites. The vessel is designed as a self-sufficient base for a wide range of project functions in moderately deep littoral waters, typically limited to 500 m. These operations include remote sensing equipment that includes autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) and various multibeam systems, the deployment of ROVs, data and media processing and other research functions. Hercules is equipped with a dynamic positioning system and advanced data processing capabilities, as well as adequate deck space and lifting systems to transport and deploy survey equipment. Potential sites are verified and documented with ROV investigation. The ROV is employed for video and image documentation, sampling, artifact retrieval, and limited excavation of sites.{{cite journal |author=Hvistendahl, Mara |title=The Adriatic's Uncharted Past |journal=[[Archaeology (magazine)|Archaeology]] |year=2011 |volume=64 |issue=2 |url=http://archive.archaeology.org/1103/features/adriatic_shipwrecks_albania.html |accessdate=2013-05-17}} The ROV is also employed for the excavation of deep-water sites; an excavation methodological process that RPMNF is helping to advance within the field of [[maritime archaeology]]. RPMNF research vessel R/V ''Hercules'' is Maltese flagged and based in [[Valletta]], Malta during the winter months. This research vessel can be deployed throughout the Mediterranean on a project basis. ==History== [[File:RPMNF expedition areas through 2014.png|thumbnail|RPMNF expedition areas through 2014]] The foundation was established in 2001 by its President, George Robb, who was a Director for the Institute of Nautical Archaeology. As part of RPMNF's initial foundation, it was establishes as a supporting institute for the Institute of Nautical Archaeology Early field work centered in Florida and select supporting projects in the Mediterranean. In 2003, Dr. Jeff Royal became Archaeological Director, then in 2011 took over as Executive Director, during which time RPMNF's focus has centered on the Mediterranean. At the end of 2010, RPMNF entered into an agreement and is a supporting institute for the Program in Maritime Studies at [[East Carolina University]]. RPMNF continues to grow its associations with Universities, individual scholars, students, and new countries around the Mediterranean.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
==Institutional Partners== * Albanian Institute of Archaeology{{cite journal |author=Smith, DM |title=Submerged Cultural Resource Discoveries in Albania: Surveys of Ancient Shipwreck Sites |year=2009 |journal=In: Pollock NW, ed. Diving for Science 2009. Proceedings of the [[American Academy of Underwater Sciences]] 28th Symposium. Dauphin Island, AL |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/10124 |accessdate=2013-05-17}} * [[Croatian Ministry of Culture]] * East Carolina University Maritime Studies * [[Institute of Nautical Archaeology]] * Malta Ministry of Culture and Tourism * Montenegro Ministry of Culture * Moroccan Ministry of Culture * Superintendent of Archaeology, Calabria * Superintendent of Underwater Archaeology, Sicily * Tunisian Ministry of Culture ==Project History== [[File:Maritimearchaeologistworking.jpg|thumbnail|left]] RPMNF's cooperative projects have proved successful in the identification, mapping, and recording of shipwreck sites and harbor works from the ancient through modern eras. To date, project areas include Spain, Albania, Montenegro, Croatia, Malta, Morocco, Cyprus, Sicily, Amalfi and Calabria in Italy, Tunisia, and Turkey. As all archaeological work is performed in conjunction with the host country’s cultural authority, the one of the crucial outcomes is that the projects assist in both scholarly research and educational projects. All recovered artifacts remain under the jurisdiction of the host government for educational/research purposes and eventual museum display in each country. The location and assessment data of wreck sites has proved beneficial to the many governments with which RPMNF have worked as it provides their cultural authorities pertinent information for protecting their submerged archaeological resources. Bathymetric data is also made available to host country hydrographic departments in order to supplement their oceanographic mapping programs. RPMNF research vessel Hercules is flagged in Malta, where it based in Valletta during the off-season, and is deployed throughout the Mediterranean on a project basis. ==Publications== RPMNF Project reports are filed with the appropriate government agency in each country. Scholarly articles from RPMNF field work are published. [[File:Herc Alb sm.jpg|frame|10 px|R/V ''Hercules'' surveying in Albania. photo D. Smith, RPMNF]] ==See also== *[[Archaeology of shipwrecks]] *[[Underwater archaeology]] *[[Nautical Archaeology Society]] *[[Sea Research Society|Sea Research Society (Shipwrecks & Underwater Archaeology)]] *[[Underwater acoustics]] *[[Underwater Archaeology Centre]] *[[Underwater search and recovery]] *[[UNESCO Convention on the Protection of the Underwater Cultural Heritage]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Maritime archaeology]]

[[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] (2000–2003) | picture_format = NTSC | audio_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|1949|03|01}} | last_aired = {{End date|2003|08|20}}| followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''''[[Ripley's Believe It or Not!]]''''' is the name of several [[documentary film|documentary television series]] based on the newspaper feature. The first series aired on [[NBC]] from 1949 to 1950, and was hosted by [[Robert L. Ripley]] until his death, after which several substitute hosts filled in. The series was revived for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] in the 1980s, and was hosted primarily by [[Jack Palance]]. Another revival debuted on [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] in 2000, and aired until 2003, with [[Dean Cain]] as host. A Filipino version, hosted by [[Chris Tiu]], debuted in 2008. An animated series based on the ''Ripley's'' franchise was also created. ==Original series (1949–1950)== The first ''Believe It or Not!'' TV series, a live show hosted by [[Robert L. Ripley]], premiered on [[NBC]] television on March 1, 1949. Shortly after the 13th episode, on May 27, 1949, Ripley died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] and several of his friends substituted as host, including future ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' president [[Doug Storer]]. Robert St. John served as host from the second season until the series ended on October 5, 1950. In 1956, [[Worldvision Enterprises|ABC Films Syndication]] had John Gibbs and Meridian Pictures prepare a ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' [[television pilot]].{{cite news|title=ABC Film Synd. Plans for Big 1956|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yB4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69|accessdate=May 6, 2015|work=Billboard|date=January 28, 1956|page=8}} ==Revival (1982–1986)== ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' later returned to television in a second series from 1982 to 1986,{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} on the American [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] network. Actor [[Jack Palance]] hosted the popular series throughout its run, while three different co-hosts appeared from season to season, including Palance's daughter, Holly Palance, actress [[Catherine Shirriff]], and singer [[Marie Osmond]]. The 1980s series reran on the [[Sci-fi Channel]] (UK) and Sci-fi Channel (US) during the 1990s. ==Animated series (1999)== In December 1995, development was underway by [[Cookie Jar Group|Cinar]] for an animated series based on ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!''.{{cite news|title=Wendel Mans Cinar's Front|url=https://variety.com/1995/more/news/wendel-mans-cinar-s-front-99123591/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=December 17, 1995}} The 26-episode series, titled ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'', was co-produced by French production company [[Alphanim]], which was founded in 1997. The series premiered on [[Freeform (TV channel)|Fox Family Channel]] on July 14, 1999,{{cite news|last=Kilmer|first=David|title=Alphanim announces new productions|url=https://www.awn.com/news/alphanim-announces-new-productions|accessdate=June 14, 2017|work=Animation World Network|date=June 13, 1999}} and was about three young people who discover unexplained mysteries and unusual items.{{cite news|last1=Amidi|first1=Amid|title=Animation and Fox Family Channel: a perfect match!|url=https://www.awn.com/news/animation-and-fox-family-channel-perfect-match|accessdate=June 14, 2017|work=[[Animation World Network]]|date=March 17, 1999}} ==Second revival (2000–2003)== In March 1994, a pilot for ''The New Ripley's Believe It or Not'' had been ordered for ABC.{{cite news|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title=Fleet of pilots ready|url=https://variety.com/1994/tv/news/fleet-of-pilots-ready-119378/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=March 20, 1994}} In December 1998, [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS Superstation]] outbid two broadcast network competitors to purchase the rights from [[Columbia TriStar Television]] Distribution for 22 hour-long episodes of ''The New Ripley's Believe It or Not'', to premiere on TBS in January 2000. The series would air weekly, and would be an update of the earlier program that aired from 1982 to 1986. The new series was to involve correspondents being sent around the world to report on amazing and unusual subjects. TBS had an option to purchase additional seasons, and had won the rights because it agreed to a full season without seeing a pilot.{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Richard|title='Believe it,' TBS says: Cabler orders 22 segs of CTTD's 'New Ripley's' series|url=https://variety.com/1998/tv/news/believe-it-tbs-says-1117489310/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=December 9, 1998}}{{cite news|last=Snow|first=Shauna|title=Arts And Entertainment Reports From The Times, News Services And The Nation's Press.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/dec/12/entertainment/ca-53070|accessdate=April 4, 2017|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=December 12, 1998}} In June 1999, Erik Nelson was signed on to serve as executive producer for the series.{{cite news|last=Dempsey|first=John|title='Ripley's' taps Nelson as exec producer: TBS series to make its debut in January|url=https://variety.com/1999/tv/news/ripley-s-taps-nelson-as-exec-producer-1117503344/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=June 22, 1999}} In December 1999, [[Dean Cain]] was hired to host the new series.{{cite news|last=Wolk|first=Josh|title=Britney Spears and LFO team up|url=http://ew.com/article/1999/12/10/britney-spears-and-lfo-team/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=December 10, 1999|quote=Dean Cain has been hired to host TBS' new version of "Ripley's Believe It or Not" (which is exactly where Cain would have filed this news if — while he was starring as Superman on "Lois and Clark" — you had told him this is where his career would take him). The series debuts Jan. 12. }} Cain also served as a producer on the show, alongside [[Dan Jbara]]. The new series, simply titled ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'', premiered on TBS on January 12, 2000.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Allan|title=Back On The Beat|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-01-09/entertainment/0001090065_1_dennis-franz-gritty-cop-drama-steven-bochco/2|accessdate=April 4, 2017|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 9, 2000}} The series was primarily shot at a 15,000 square-foot Ripley's warehouse in [[Sylmar, Los Angeles]].{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Tricia|title=Wack & Cheese: The Ripley's Believe It or Not! set features props both tacky and terrifying|url=http://ew.com/article/2002/06/14/wack-cheese/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 14, 2002}} Most episodes open with an act that is performed in front of a live audience, while the rest of the episode involves Cain introducing various segments, each one for a different subject. [[Gregory Jbara]] served as one of the narrators for the different segments. [[Kelly Packard]] became a field correspondent in 2002, and would host coverage of events in which people demonstrate their unusual abilities, usually in front of an audience. The show also features such regular elements as "Spot the Not," a weekly [[trivia]] segment in which viewers are challenged to pick the claim that is not real and a special "Ripley's Record" commemoration for people who break a [[world record]] while appearing on the show. [[Rerun]]s of the series began airing on The WB in September 2001,{{cite news|last=Adalian|first=Josef|title=ATG morning after|url=https://variety.com/2001/tv/news/atg-morning-after-1117851509/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=August 20, 2001}}{{cite news|last=Schneider|first=Michael|title=Big six overview: WB|url=https://variety.com/2001/biz/news/big-six-overview-wb-1117852682/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=September 13, 2001}} and were expected to continue until December 2001.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Allan|title=Another 'Mole' role|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-08-23/features/0108230005_1_producer-scott-stone-mole-ii-saboteur|accessdate=April 4, 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|date=August 23, 2001}} In early 2003, Sony Pictures Television ordered an 11-episode fourth season. In March 2003, 11 additional episodes were ordered for the fourth season, which aired on Wednesday evenings at 9:00 p.m. For its timeslot, the series was the top-rated program among its target audience of people between the ages of 18-34, 18-49 and 25-54.{{cite news|last=Oei|first=Lily|title=TBS orders up 'Ripley': Series is top-rated in its timeslot among adult demos|url=https://variety.com/2003/tv/news/tbs-orders-up-ripley-1117882560/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=March 17, 2003}} In September 2003, Sony Pictures announced a trimmed half-hour version of the existing show that would start airing in reruns on local television channels across the United States.{{cite news|last=Dempsey|first=John|title=Cablers raise syndie stakes|url=https://variety.com/2003/tv/news/cablers-raise-syndie-stakes-1117892381/|accessdate=May 23, 2017|work=Variety|date=September 14, 2003}} Reruns later began airing on Canada's [[Space (Canadian TV channel)|SPACE station]] as of 2012. As of 2017, hour-long reruns aired on [[Chiller (TV network)|Chiller]]. ==2008 version== {{Main|Ripley's Believe It or Not! (2008 TV series)}} In 2008, a new version of the series, hosted by [[Chris Tiu]], began airing on [[GMA Network]], a Filipino television channel. ==See also== * [[List of Ripley's Believe It or Not! episodes (1982–86)]] * [[List of Ripley's Believe It or Not! episodes (2000–03)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0083473|Ripley's Believe It or Not (1982-1986)}} * {{IMDb title|0218787|Ripley's Believe It or Not (1999-2003)}} * [http://www.tv.com/show/10278/summary.html TV.com summary (third run)] * [http://www.angelfire.com/mn/nn/r101.html ''Ripley's Believe It Or Not!''] fan site with episode descriptions and video clips of the 1980s and 2000s (decade) series {{TBSNetwork Shows|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ripley's Believe It Or Not (Tv Series)}} [[Category:Ripley's Believe It or Not!]] [[Category:1940s American television series]] [[Category:1950s American television series]] [[Category:1980s American television series]] [[Category:1990s American television series]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:1949 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1950 American television series endings]] [[Category:1982 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1986 American television series endings]] [[Category:1999 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1999 American television series endings]] [[Category:2000 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2003 American television series endings]] [[Category:Live television programs]] [[Category:American non-fiction television series]] [[Category:NBC network shows]] [[Category:American Broadcasting Company network shows]] [[Category:TBS (U.S. TV channel) programs]] [[Category:Gaumont Animation]] [[Category:American documentary television series]] [[Category:American anthology television series]] [[Category:Television series by Sony Pictures Television]] [[Category:Television series by Lionsgate Television]] [[Category:Television programs based on comic strips]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:American television series revived after cancellation]] [[Category:American children's television series]] [[Category:Television series about urban legends]]

The '''Society of Architectural Historians of Great Britain''' ('''SAHGB''') is a [[United Kingdom]] [[learned society]] for people interested in the [[history of architecture]].<ref>[http://www.sahgb.org.uk/about.html About US], ''Society of Architectural Historians of Great Britain''.</ref><ref>[http://wiki-riba01.seoss.co.uk/wiki/The_Society_of_Architectural_Historians_of_Great_Britain The Society of Architectural Historians of Great Britain] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206021321/http://wiki-riba01.seoss.co.uk/wiki/The_Society_of_Architectural_Historians_of_Great_Britain |date=2008-12-06 }}, [[RIBApedia]].</ref><ref>[http://openlibrary.org/a/OL5265410A Society of Architectural Historians of Great Britain], [[Open Library]].</ref>
== Purpose ==
The Society exists to encourage interest in the history of architecture, to enable the exchange and discussion of ideas related to this. The Society has no official location and its activities cover the [[United Kingdom]]. The Society also represents the interests of UK architectural history to governmental and non-governmental bodies within the education and heritage fields. The Society specifically avoids conservation issues.
''[[Architectural History (journal)|Architectural History]]'' is the main journal of the society.<ref>[http://www.sahgb.org.uk/index.cfm/display_page/Publications Publications: Architectural History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110311062734/http://www.sahgb.org.uk/index.cfm/display_page/Publications |date=2011-03-11 }}, ''Society of Architectural Historians of Great Britain''.</ref> It is published each autumn and members of SAHBG receive a copy. There is also a newsletter for members.
== History ==
The foundation of the Society was prompted in 1955 by [[Turpin Bannister]] in discussion with [[Frank Jenkins (architect)|Frank Jenkins]], a British architect and scholar who worked with Bannister at the [[University of Illinois]] in the [[United States]]. Initially it was conceived as being a chapter of the American [[Society of Architectural Historians]] partly because Bannister had been a founder-member in 1940. However, it was decided in 1956 that the Society should be independent. The early members were mainly architects and teachers. The Chairmen of the first meetings were Bruce Allsopp and William A. Singleton, the latter affiliated with the [[York Institute of Architectural Study]].

{{About|the Knoxville, Tennessee television series|other works with similar names|Heartland (disambiguation)}} '''''The Heartland Series''''' is a series of [[television program]]s about the culture of [[Appalachia]], produced by [[WBIR-TV]] of [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], over the 25-year period 1984 through 2009. The series has been produced on a limited basis since 2010.
==Production history== ''The Heartland Series'' was conceived in 1984 to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the founding of the [[Great Smoky Mountains National Park]] with a special series celebrating the people and land of the Southern Appalachian Mountains.<ref name=Shearer/> Actor [[Bill Landry]] was hired to host the series. He had previously been a teacher, had written and begun performing a one-man [[Play (theater)|play]] based on the life of [[Albert Einstein]] called "Einstein the Man," and had portrayed a fictional [[Tennessee River]] boat captain named "Captain Nat" as part of the [[Tennessee Valley Authority]] (TVA) exhibit at the [[1982 World's Fair]] in Knoxville. Following the fair, he had continued to play the role of Captain Nat on a months-long [[barge]] tour of the Tennessee, [[Cumberland River|Cumberland]], and [[Mississippi River]]s that TVA conducted for its 50th anniversary.<ref name=Shearer/><ref name=AboutLandry/><ref>[http://www.tva.gov/heritage/worldsfair/index.htm When the World Came to TVA], Tennessee Valley Authority website, accessed October 14, 2009</ref>
The TV series was initially scheduled to run for just three months.<ref name=Tupper>Leean Tupper, [http://www.oakridger.com/localnews/x2121669764/Goodbye-Heartland-Series-melded-the-generations Goodbye: 'Heartland Series' melded the generations] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928025646/http://www.oakridger.com/localnews/x2121669764/Goodbye-Heartland-Series-melded-the-generations |date=2011-09-28 }}, ''[[The Oak Ridger]]'', August 14, 2009</ref> According to Landry, the original concept, formed by WBIR creative services director Steve Dean and station general manager Jim Hart, was "to take a [[video camera|camera]] and interview the last remnants of the old mountain people and go on location.”<ref name=Shearer/> Each episode was three minutes and 40 seconds long,<ref name=Shearer/> designed to air in five-minute time slots during and after daily news broadcasts.
The series continued past the short run that was originally planned. Subject matter included [[geology]], wildlife, native plants, [[invasive species]], and other aspects of the region's [[natural history]], [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] lifeways and [[archeology]], re-enactments and remembrances of historical events ranging from events in the [[American Revolutionary War]] to [[coal mining]] disasters and the early years of TVA, and feature stories about regional culture.<ref name=Morrow>Terry Morrow, [http://blogs.knoxnews.com/knx/telebuddy/archives/2009/02/wbir_stops_prod.shtml WBIR stops production of 'The Heartland Series'], Tele-Buddy's Tinseltown Tales, knoxnews.com, February 12, 2009</ref> As a result of his work on the series, host Bill Landry told an interviewer that he had learned to “[[Tanning (leather)|tan hides]], make jelly butter, saw logs, eat tree bark, carve [[soapstone]], build a [[log cabin]], cut timber, run a [[sawmill]], make [[moonshine]], [[Horseshoe|shoe a horse]], call a [[barred owl|hoot owl]], [[Rut (mammalian reproduction)|rut]] like a [[deer]] and know when the [[American bison|buffalo]] runs.”<ref name=Brownwrapping/> Traditional music was a perennial topic, including performances by and interviews with traditional musicians active in East Tennessee,<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=3&StoryID=31 A Music Tale], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref><ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=5&StoryID=1 Hardware Pickers], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> demonstrations by craftsmen who make musical instruments,<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=6&StoryID=15 Artist in Residence - Fiddle Making], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> and exploration of musical traditions such as [[old harp singing]]<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=2&StoryID=17 Singing the Old Harp], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> and Scottish and Irish influences on the region's music.<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=7&StoryID=10 Ballads in Time], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> Two topics that the series generally avoided were [[politics]] and controversial religious practices such as [[snake handling]].<ref name=Smyser>Dick Smyser, Short takes and tall tales from Bill Landry's 'Heartland', ''[[The Oak Ridger]]'', November 10, 1998</ref> In addition to the Smokies national park, on-scene production locations in East Tennessee included the [[Museum of Appalachia]], where several episodes were taped, including the titles "1791," "Just Another Day," "The Music Tale," "The Toggins," "Frontier Music, Frontier Foods," and "Gift for Jacob,"<ref name=Tupper/> [[Rugby, Tennessee|Rugby]],<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=4&StoryID=25 The Glory of Rugby], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> [[Roan Mountain State Park]],<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=5&StoryID=28 Roan Mountain Pilgrimage], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> the [[Savage Gulf State Natural Area]] in [[Grundy County, Tennessee|Grundy County]],<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=5&StoryID=4 Wilderness Spared], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref> and [[Cumberland Gap National Historical Park]].<ref>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=5&StoryID=2 Hensley], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website, accessed October 16, 2009</ref>
Landry's skill as an [[interview]]er has been remarked upon by many observers. His folksy, rambling style made him effective at putting people at ease and drawing out the interesting stories of the people that he encountered in the "hills, hollows, small towns and major cities" of Appalachia.<ref name=Brownwrapping/><ref name=Smyser/><ref name=Venable/>
In 1998, the series was expanded to include a 30-minute version airing each Saturday at 7:00 p.m., while it continued to run the original five-minute version during the morning news, after ''10 News at Noon'', and after ''10 News Nightbeat''.<ref name=AboutLandry>[http://staging.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/b_landry.aspx About Bill Landry], WBIR website, accessed October 6, 1009</ref>
In total, about 1,900 short episodes and 150 half-hour programs were produced in the show's 25-year history.<ref name=Brownwrapping>Fred Brown, [http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2009/apr/13/landry-concludes-25-years-sheartland-series/ 'Heartland Series' wrapping up after 25 years], ''[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]'', April 13, 2009</ref> Bill Landry was host and narrator for the entire series.<ref name=Brown/> He also served as co-producer and wrote and directed many episodes.<ref>[http://www.oakridger.com/community/x1588597869/Heartlands-Bill-Landry-speaks-at-Arboretum-Society-meeting Heartland's Bill Landry speaks at Arboretum Society meeting], ''[[The Oak Ridger]]'', October 30, 2008</ref> Steve Dean was executive producer for 20 years, and Doug Mills was cameraman for all but one of the episodes.<ref name=Brown/><ref name=TimesNews>[http://www.timesnews.net/article.php?id=3759185 'Heartland Series' creator to speak at J. Frank White Academy commencement], ''Kingsport Times News'', May 13, 2007</ref>
The series has been successful with audiences, sometimes achieving [[Audience measurement|audience ratings]] of 7.0 or higher.<ref name=Morrow/> In addition to being broadcast on WBIR, the series appeared on [[WTVC]] in [[Chattanooga]] during the 1980s and was shown on the [[Travel Channel]] (under the title ''Appalachian Stories'') for six years.<ref name=Shearer>John Shearer, [http://www.chattanoogan.com/articles/article_156006.asp Former Chattanoogan Landry Had 25-Year Run With Popular Appalachian Features], The Chattanoogan, August 2, 2009</ref><ref name=TimesNews/>
===End of production=== In February 2009, WBIR announced plans to suspend production of the series in September 2009 after taking it "through to some sort of conclusion."<ref name=Morrow/> WBIR general manager Jeff Lee cited economics as the reason for ending production, noting "it is a luxury for three people to produce 3-1/2 minutes of TV a week."<ref name=Morrow/><ref name=Brownwrapping/> He said that the station would continue to show the hundreds of episodes already produced "for as long as the viewers like them."<ref name=Morrow/> More than 3,000 people signed an online [[petition]] asking for the series to be continued, but WBIR followed through with its plan to end it.<ref name=Morrowprime/> The last episode was taped at the [[Museum of Appalachia]] in [[Norris, Tennessee|Norris]] on August 8, 2009 before an audience estimated at 10,000 people, one of the largest crowds in the museum's history.<ref name=Brown/><ref name=Morrowfans>Terry Morrow, [http://blogs.knoxnews.com/telebuddy/archives/2009/08/10000_fans_turn.shtml 10,000 fans turn out for last 'Heartland Series' taping] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019224041/http://blogs.knoxnews.com/telebuddy/archives/2009/08/10000_fans_turn.shtml |date=2009-10-19 }}, Knoxnews.com, August 12, 2009</ref> People seeking Landry's [[autograph]] waited in line for an hour.<ref name=Morrowfans/> The final show featured several [[Appalachian traditional music]]ians who had appeared previously in the series, including [[fiddler]] [[Danny Gammon]], [[Bobby Fulcher]], [[Tony Thomas (bluegrass musician)|Tony Thomas]] and [[Jimmy McCarroll]].<ref name=Brown>Fred Brown, [http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2009/aug/09/heartland-says-goodbye/ 'Heartland Series' says goodbye; Many turn out to celebrate longtime WBIR series], Knoxville News Sentinel, August 9, 2009</ref>
The last episode was scheduled for broadcast as an hour-long special on September 19, 2009, but to avoid conflict with a [[Tennessee Volunteers]] football game the broadcast was postponed and rescheduled to be shown in a [[prime time]] slot at 8:00 p.m. on October 17, 2009.<ref>Terry Morrow, [http://blogs.knoxnews.com/telebuddy/archives/2009/09/wbir_sets_date.shtml WBIR sets date for 'Heartland Series' finale], KnoxNews.com, September 8, 2009</ref><ref>Terry Morrow, [http://blogs.knoxnews.com/telebuddy/archives/2009/09/heartland_serie.shtml 'Heartland Series' finale postponed], KnoxNews.com, September 17, 2009</ref><ref name=Morrowprime>Terry Morrow, [http://blogs.knoxnews.com/telebuddy/archives/2009/10/heartland_serie_1.shtml 'Heartland Series' finale to go primetime], KnoxNews.com, October 6, 2009</ref>
===Revival===
Public response to the cancellation of the series caused management to reconsider its demise. In 2010 producer Steve Dean was contracted to produce four more episodes, each an hour long.<ref>[http://www.wbir.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=116170 New Heartland Series program to air in March], WBIR-TV website, March 17, 2010. Accessed March 2, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.maryvillecollege.edu/news/1312/ Upcoming Heartland Series to include Maryville College as part of its hour-long special on Sept. 25], [[Maryville College]] press release, September 21, 2010</ref><ref>[http://heartland.wbir.com/story.aspx?storyid=144216&catid=35 Heartland crew shoots scenes for Christmas special], WBIR-TV website, November 24, 2010. Accessed March 2, 2011.</ref> These shows were well received and led to new hour-long installments, to be produced quarterly, through 2011.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
==Recognition and influence== During its 25-year history, ''The Heartland Series'' received four [[Emmy Award]]s, six [[Iris Award]]s from the [[NATPE|National Association of Television Program Executives]], one silver medal and two bronze medals from the [[New York International Film and Television Festival]], and a Theodore Roosevelt Award for Best Outdoor Documentary.<ref>[http://www.knoxvilletennessee.com/news.html Knoxville News / Knoxville Weather], KnoxvilleTennessee.com website, accessed October 6, 2009</ref>
On the day that the last episode was taped, former [[U.S. Senator]] [[Howard Baker]], who had appeared in one episode, called the series "the last iteration of our history and culture of a generation."<ref name=Brown/> Mark Brown, [[Carson Newman College]]'s director of news and media relations, described the series as "the nation's longest-running sociological video repository" and said "it did for Southern Appalachia what [[Studs Terkel]] did for [[Chicago]]."<ref name=Venable>Sam Venable, [http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2009/sep/18/whichever-way-the-wind-blows/ Whichever way the wind blows], ''[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]'', September 18, 2009</ref>
Thousands of hours of never-broadcast [[videotape]]s made during the show's 25-year history are being archived in the historical collection of the [[Frank H. McClung Museum|McClung Museum]] in Knoxville.<ref name=Brown/> Episodes from the series have been incorporated into [[Appalachian studies]] curricula,<ref>[http://www.east-tennessee-history.org/file/Appalachia%20Lesson%20Plans.pdf Teaching Tennessee History: Lesson Plans for the Classroom, Volume IV], East Tennessee Historical Society, 2003</ref> and ''The Heartland Series'' videos depicting Appalachian [[crafts]] and craftspeople are displayed in the "Appalachian Heritage" exhibit of the [[Children's Museum of Oak Ridge]].<ref>[http://www.oakridger.com/entertainment/x1157493646/Appalachian-Heritage-Exhibit-grand-opening-Nov-8-at-Childrens-Museum Appalachian Heritage Exhibit grand opening Nov. 8 at Children's Museum], ''[[The Oak Ridger]]'', October 22, 2008</ref> [[United States embassies]] around the world keep tapes of ''The Heartland Series'' broadcasts as an information resource on life in Appalachia.<ref>[http://www.gannett.com/about/map/ataglance/knoxvil.htm WBIR-TV], [[Gannett]] website, accessed October 6, 2009</ref>
==Theme music== The theme music for ''The Heartland Series'' is an arrangement of the ancient [[Gaels|Gaelic]] ballad "He Mandu," which is played on the [[hammered dulcimer]] by folklorist [[Guy Carawan]].<ref>[http://www.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/hlstory.aspx?VolID=9&StoryID=6 The Hammer Dulcimer], Heartland episode description, WBIR-TV website. Retrieved: 7 October 2009.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.wbir.com/life/programming/local/heartland/default.aspx WBIR-TV Heartland Videos]

[[File:Siddham LOGO.jpg|thumb|]] [[File:Zenodo logo.jpg|thumb|]] '''Siddham''' or the '''Asia Inscriptions Database''' is an open-access resource for the study of inscriptions from South, Central and South East Asia. Siddham was established by the [[European Research Council]] with start-up funding from the project [[Beyond Boundaries: Religion, Region, Language and the State]]. The first focus of Siddham is [[Sanskrit]] [[epigraphy]], mainly of the fourth, fifth and sixth centuries CE, but the platform is designed to accommodate inscriptions from all periods. In South Asia alone, the estimated number of historic inscriptions is 90,000.<ref>Salomon, Richard. ''Indian Epigraphy: A Guide to the Study of Inscriptions in Sanskrit, Prakrit, and the Other Indo-Aryan Languages''. New York: Oxford University Press, 1998.</ref> In its next phases, Siddham will expand to include inscriptions in [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Kannada]], [[Prakrit]], [[Classical Tibetan|Tibetan]], [[Burmese language|Burmese]], [[Pyu language (Burma)|Pyu]] and [[Mon language|Mon]].
==Etymology== In [[Sanskrit]] ''siddhaṃ'' means "success, accomplished, perfected." It was also symbolism and substitution for an "auspicious sign" found in the oldest inscriptions of the South Asia. In some cases, siddham is not spelled out, but indicated with a sign such as ''[[Om]]'' or a ''srivasta'', and various scholars consider ''siddham'' in inscriptions to be equivalent to these signs.<ref name="Salomon1998p67"/><ref>Lore Sander (1986), ''Om or Siddham–Remarks on Openings of Buddhist Manuscripts and Inscriptions from Gilgit and Central Asia'', in Deyadharma: Studies in Memory of Dr. DC Sircar, pages 251-261</ref>
This word, written out in characters (such as those shown in the Siddham logo) or represented by a symbol, often stands at the beginning of inscriptions in Indic languages.<ref name="Salomon1998p67">{{cite book|author=Richard Salomon|title=Indian Epigraphy: A Guide to the Study of Inscriptions in Sanskrit, Prakrit, and the other Indo-Aryan Languages |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XYrG07qQDxkC&pg=PA67 |year=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-535666-3|pages=67–68}}</ref> The term ''Siddham'' is also used as a short name for the Indian script known as [[Siddhaṃ_script|siddhamātṛkā]].
==Technical background== The records in Siddham have been prepared in [[EpiDoc]], a tool for structured [[markup language|markup]] of [[epigraphy|epigraphic]] documents in [[Text Encoding Initiative|TEI]] [[XML]].
==Numbering system== Within Siddham, each item is listed firstly as an object -- such as a pillar, sculpture, copper-plate, stone slab and so forth. Each object may carry one or more inscriptions, thus each inscription has been assigned a separate Siddham number. A good example is the [[Allahabad pillar]] -- a single object -- which carries many inscriptions, among them those of Aśoka, [[Samudragupta]] and Jahāngīr.<ref>Falk, Harry. ''Aśokan Sites and Artefacts: A Source-Book with Bibliography''. Mainz am Rhein: Ph. von Zabern, 2006.</ref> The inscription of Samdragupta appears in Siddham as IN00001.<ref>See: http://siddham.uk/object/ob00001</ref> All material generated for SIDDHAṂ is archived in [[Zenodo]].
The further example illustrated here is from [[Salihundam]], Gara Mandal, Srikakulam district, [[Andhra Pradesh]], India, a Buddhist place located approximately at 18°20'7"N 84°2'28"E. At this site, a series of five votive inscriptions are engraved on the semi-circular threshold of a ruined shrine. In Siddham, the semi-circular stone will carry an object number and each votive record an independent inscription number. The photograph of the inscriptions is archived as Zenodo. http://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.557032. [[File:Salihundam votive inscriptions.jpg|thumb|Salihundam, Andhra Pradesh. Votive inscriptions. In SIDDHAṂ the semi-circular threshold will have an object number, and each votive record an inscription number.]]
[[File:Erc-logo.jpg|thumb|]] ==Translations== Translations of inscription texts into western languages appear separately in the community called '''SIDDHAṂ traductions''' in [[Zenodo]]. Each translation is numbered according to the inscription number assigned in Siddham.
==Mapping== Epigraphic documentation involves mapping sites of key dynasties and their inscriptions, especially land-charters recording gifts of land. The mapping undertaken to date can be explored through these links:
**[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1XBC7yj00cs_IOX-fZr16LCkRr4Y Parivrājaka and Uccakalpa dynasties and sites] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1OC_mFTBxNOYmRHleSRH-Bgk7WlU Vākāṭaka inscriptions and sites] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=19ARCfEI3jJ_FkhcqNnjapfT3XL0 Nala and Śarabhapurīya dynasties] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1DEyYPGMkPIye76qDTF7KcFHGhKY Gaṅgas, Pitṛbhaktas, Śarabhapurīyas and related dynasties] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1YyQKhqLQVTcRacBy8Vsa6QBaNYE Maitraka dynasty] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1q2oyPTVbjBKJDvIruXY63rEFWhA Kadamba dynasty] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1f4m674MGwDo7pQ1IhTgA-CxAi7w Viṣṇukundin, Śālaṅkāyana and related dynasties] **[https://www.google.com/maps/d/embed?mid=1yoD9sNXU5MAU-11VW70bEjA5oC8 Sri Lankan inscriptions and sites]
